messages.text: Hello! I am trying to use a `LazySum` of `LazyTensor` operators called `op`. I can execute `op * ket` successfully, but not `mul!(out_ket, op, ket)`. With the latter I get a method mismatch error. I would like to do the latter for benchmarking.  I see QuantumOptics calls `QuantumOpticsBase.mul!()` internally (is QuantumOpticsBase not overloading `Base.mul!`?), but this doesn't work for me either. Should this be working?

text.text: Hello! I am trying to use a `LazySum` of `LazyTensor` operators called `op`. I can execute `op * ket` successfully, but not `mul!(out_ket, op, ket)`. With the latter I get a method mismatch error. I would like to do the latter for benchmarking.  I see QuantumOptics calls `QuantumOpticsBase.mul!()` internally (is QuantumOpticsBase not overloading `Base.mul!`?), but this doesn't work for me either. Should this be working?

messages.text: On a related matter, how careful are the `LazySum` and `LazyTensor` implementations of `mul!()` or `gemm!()` with memory allocation?

text.text: On a related matter, how careful are the `LazySum` and `LazyTensor` implementations of `mul!()` or `gemm!()` with memory allocation?

messages.text: PS: Thanks to the devs of QuantumOptics. It's very cool!

text.text: PS: Thanks to the devs of QuantumOptics. It's very cool!

messages.text: @amilsted That should work, so it might be a bug. Can you share some code that reproduces the error?

text.text: @amilsted That should work, so it might be a bug. Can you share some code that reproduces the error?

messages.text: It overloads `LinearAlgebra.mul!` so calling that won't make a difference

text.text: It overloads `LinearAlgebra.mul!` so calling that won't make a difference

messages.text: The memory allocations should be small, but probably not zero

text.text: The memory allocations should be small, but probably not zero

messages.text: I tried on a simple example and `mul!(out, op, state)` works for me when op is a `LazySum` of two `LazyTensor`s
